'Lake Baringo' is, after Lake Turkana, the most northern of the Kenyan Rift
Valley lakes, with a surface area of about and an elevation of about . The lake
is fed by several rivers, Molo, Perkerra and Ol Arabel, and has no obvious
outlet; the waters are assumed to seep through lake sediments into the faulted
volcanic bedrock. It is one of the two freshwater lakes in the Rift Valley in
Kenya, the other being Lake Naivasha. See "Kenya designates
freshwater lake in Great Rift Valley," at [http://www.ramsar.org/cda/ramsar/display/main/main.jsp?zn=ramsar&cp=1-26-45-
87^22874_4000_0__ Ramsar 2009 - 2002].  It lies off the beaten track in a
hot and dusty setting and over 470 species of birds have been recorded there,
occasionally including migrating flamingos. A Goliath Heronry is located on a
rocky islet in the lake known as Gibraltar.
categories: Lakes of the Great Rift Valley
